title: Astronomers Detect a Possible Signature of Life on a Distant Planet
abstract: Further studies are needed to determine whether K2-18b, which orbits a star 120 light-years away, is inhabited, or even habitable.

title: Why Harvard Decided to Fight Trump
abstract: The Trump administration will freeze over $2 billion in federal funds because Harvard refused to comply with a list of demands. Harvard leaders believed saying no was worth the risk.

title: I Have Never Been More Afraid for My Country’s Future
abstract: Trump’s worldview is stuck in the 1970s, and his whole administration is a cruel farce.

title: Law Firms Made Deals With Trump. Now He Wants More From Them.
abstract: To avoid retribution, big firms agreed to provide free legal services for uncontroversial causes. To the White House, that could mean negotiating trade deals — or even defending the president and his allies.

title: Maryland Senator Unable to Secure Meeting With Deported Immigrant in El Salvador
abstract: Senator Chris Van Hollen, a Democrat, said he had not yet been allowed to see Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, a Salvadoran immigrant who was mistakenly deported by the Trump administration and imprisoned.

title: 2 Protesters at Marjorie Taylor Greene Town Hall Are Subdued With Stun Guns
abstract: Three people, including the two who were subdued with stun guns, were arrested.

title: I Trained at an Amazon Center in Hangzhou. You’d Be Surprised What They Think of Trump.
abstract: China’s e-commerce ecosystem illustrates how Trump’s tariffs only strengthen that country’s hand.

title: Stocks Fall as Powell Sees Tariff Challenges and Tech Pulls Back
abstract: Semiconductor stocks fell after the Trump administration blocked companies from selling certain chips to China without a license.

title: I.R.S. Is Said to Be Considering Whether to Revoke Harvard’s Tax-Exempt Status
abstract: The move would be a major escalation of the Trump administration’s attempts to choke off federal money and support for the leading research university.

title: Grassley Draws Jeers From Constituents at Raucous Town Hall
abstract: The Iowa Republican was pressed on President Trump’s policies, including the case of a Salvadoran immigrant who his administration has admitted it mistakenly sent to a prison in El Salvador.

title: I’m a Columbia Professor. Here’s the Really Disheartening Part of This Mess.
abstract: Where were these voices when the university was under assault from the Trump administration?

title: It’s Time to Protect America From America’s President
abstract: Trump’s authoritarian actions are vandalizing the American project.

title: U.K. Top Court Says Trans Women Are Not Legally Women Under Equality Act
abstract: Britain’s Supreme Court ruled that the word “woman” refers to biological sex under the country’s anti-discrimination law, in a blow to trans rights activists.

title: Musk’s Team Is Building a System to Sell ‘Gold Card’ Immigrant Visas
abstract: The project represents something of a shift in mission for Elon Musk’s initiative, from cutting government costs toward a new goal of generating revenue.

title: Patients Cut Off From Cheaper Obesity Drugs as the F.D.A. Halts Sales of Copycats
abstract: U.S. regulators are trying to shut down the industry for compounded weight-loss drugs, which could result in higher costs or suspend treatment for patients.

title: What Harvard Has Set the Stage For
abstract: The university’s willingness to stand up to the Trump administration can be a model.

title: Wife of Gene Hackman Asked About Flulike Symptoms Before Their Deaths
abstract: Videos, photographs and police reports released by the Santa Fe County Sheriff’s Office in New Mexico offered a look into the days before Betsy Arakawa and Mr. Hackman died.

title: Late Night Revels in Harvard’s Rejection of Trump’s Demand
abstract: “I don’t usually root for Harvard, because they’re Harvard. They’ve got everything. It’s like rooting for Jeff Bezos to win the lottery,” Ronny Chieng said on “The Daily Show.”

title: Trump Waved Off Israeli Strike After Divisions Emerged in His Administration
abstract: Israel developed plans for attacking Iranian nuclear facilities that would have required U.S. assistance. But some administration officials had doubts.

title: A Top Democratic Official Plots to Take Down Party Incumbents
abstract: David Hogg, a young liberal activist and now a vice chair of the Democratic National Committee, is leading an effort to unseat the party’s older lawmakers in primaries.

title: Trump Administration Will Freeze $2 Billion After Harvard Refuses Demands
abstract: Federal officials said they would freeze the money after Harvard said it would not submit to requests to overhaul hiring and report international students who break rules.

title: Suspect Charged in Arson at Pennsylvania Governor’s Mansion
abstract: A man was charged with setting fire to the residence, forcing Gov. Josh Shapiro and his family to flee. Investigators said they found beer bottles with gasoline inside the house.

title: Supreme Court Sides With Wrongly Deported Migrant
abstract: A trial judge had ordered the Trump administration to take steps to return the migrant, Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, from a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: Have We Been Thinking About A.D.H.D. All Wrong?
abstract: With diagnoses at a record high, some experts have begun to question our assumptions about the condition — and how to treat it.

title: Producing Something This Stupid Is the Achievement of a Lifetime
abstract: Maybe we’re just not good at thinking anymore.

title: White House Releases Results of Trump’s Annual Physical Exam
abstract: The report is the first public accounting of the president’s health since January, when he became the oldest man ever sworn into his office. His previous medical disclosures have drawn scrutiny.

title: Social Security Lists Thousands of Migrants as Dead to Prompt Them to ‘Self-Deport’
abstract: By placing migrants in Social Security’s “death master file,” the Trump administration is seeking to cut off their access to credit cards, bank accounts and other financial services.

title: China Halts Critical Exports as Trade War Intensifies
abstract: Beijing has suspended exports of certain rare earth minerals and magnets that are crucial for the world’s car, semiconductor and aerospace industries.

title: Michelle Obama Addresses Divorce Rumors and Public Absences
abstract: The former first lady said on a podcast that people “couldn’t even fathom that I was making a choice for myself, that they had to assume that my husband and I are divorcing.”

title: A Lot About Trump Doesn’t Add Up
abstract: A very petty man in a very powerful job.

title: The Vibe Shifts Against the Right
abstract: People who once found right-wing ideas scintillating are having second thoughts as they watch Trump put those ideas into practice.

title: 5 Science-Backed Longevity ‘Hacks’ That Don’t Cost a Fortune
abstract: You don’t need a $40,000 gym membership to live a longer, healthier life.

title: From ‘Be Cool!’ to ‘Getting Yippy’: Inside Trump’s Reversal on Tariffs
abstract: Economic turmoil, particularly a rapid rise in government bond yields, caused President Trump to reverse course on the steep levies.

title: Columbia Activist Arrested by ICE at His Appointment for Citizenship
abstract: Mohsen Mahdawi, a legal permanent resident, has lived in the United States for 10 years and was arrested in Vermont. He has not been charged with a crime.

title: James Carville: How to Turn Trump’s Economic Chaos Against Him
abstract: Tie the president to the people’s pain, and make the message local.

title: Musk’s Latest Fraud Finding Isn’t What It Seems
abstract: His team found cases of seemingly fake people receiving unemployment benefits. But that fake data exists for a reason.

title: She’s Young, Trump-Friendly, and Has a White House Press Pass
abstract: Natalie Winters, a protégée of Stephen Bannon, belongs to a newly high-profile contingent of West Wing reporters.

title: Val Kilmer, Film Star Who Played Batman and Jim Morrison, Dies at 65
abstract: A wide-ranging leading man who earned critical praise, he was known to be charismatic but unpredictable. At one point he dropped out of Hollywood for a decade.

title: Hillary Clinton: How Much Dumber Will This Get?
abstract: The Signal group chat is only the latest in a string of self-inflicted wounds by the new administration.

title: 10 Small Things Neurologists Wish You’d Do for Your Brain
abstract: Easy everyday habits can help keep you sharp. And it’s never too late to start them.

title: Cory Booker Condemns Trump’s Policies in Longest Senate Speech on Record
abstract: The New Jersey senator spent much of his speech, which ended after more than 25 hours, assailing the Trump administration. He eclipsed Strom Thurmond’s filibuster of a civil rights bill in 1957.

title: The Secret History of the War in Ukraine
abstract: This is the untold story of America’s hidden role in Ukrainian military operations against Russia’s invading armies.

title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

title: The Leaked Signal Chat, Annotated
abstract: The chat’s contents, which were obtained by The Atlantic after its editor in chief was added to the Signal group, provide a revealing look at private conversations between top Trump administration officials.

title: Latest Polls: Do Americans Approve of President Trump?
abstract: Track the latest polls about Americans’ approval of President Trump.

title: He Was Held Captive in His Room for Decades. Then He Set It on Fire.
abstract: Firefighters found a 32-year-old man who weighed 68 pounds. The police say his stepmother locked him away when he was 12.

title: Pentagon Set Up Briefing for Musk on Potential War With China
abstract: The access would be a major expansion of Elon Musk’s government role and highlight his conflicts of interest.

title: How to Protect Your Retirement Savings Now as Markets Plunge
abstract: If you’re within five years of retiring, either before or after, you’re at your most vulnerable financially. Here are steps to weather the volatility.

title: Mass Protests Across the Country Show Resistance to Trump
abstract: Demonstrators packed the streets in cities and towns to rail against government cutbacks, financial turmoil and what they viewed as attacks on democracy.

title: The Gen X Career Meltdown
abstract: Just when they should be at their peak, experienced workers in creative fields find that their skills are all but obsolete.

title: Wisconsin Spring Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

title: Wall Street Bursts With Anger Over Tariff ‘Stupidity’
abstract: Billionaire investors are in an unfamiliar position, watching and cringing as tariffs roll on and the stock market reels.

title: Trump’s Threats Force Institutions to Choose: Cut a Deal or Fight Back
abstract: In a hint of a shift in strategy, some of the country’s most powerful institutions have started choosing to resist.

title: Space Travel and Tuberculosis Research Are Hit by Trump’s Harvard Cuts
abstract: Researchers who have lost funds warned of long-term repercussions, but several said their school should still refuse to comply with the federal government.

title: Judge Threatens Contempt Proceedings Over Deportation Flights to El Salvador
abstract: The move was a remarkable attempt by a jurist to hold the White House accountable for its apparent willingness to flout court orders.

title: Mother of Woman Killed by Immigrant Speaks at White House Briefing
abstract: The appearance by Patty Morin came as a federal judge threatened the Trump administration with a contempt-of-court investigation over its deportation flights to El Salvador.

title: L.A.’s Schools Chief Knows What It’s Like to Be Undocumented
abstract: A visit by federal agents to two elementary schools drew an angry, impassioned response from the superintendent, Alberto Carvalho, a Portuguese immigrant.

title: A Columbia Activist Sought Middle Ground on Gaza. The U.S. Detained Him.
abstract: Mohsen Mahdawi was arrested at a citizenship interview in Vermont. He had spent a decade trying to understand the conflict that shaped his life, his supporters say.

title: Texas Is Poised to Create a $1 Billion Private School Voucher Program
abstract: The Texas House approved the plan, part of a push by President Trump’s allies to offer up to about $10,000 for private school, home-school or virtual learning.

title: Iran Says Shifting U.S. Messages on Nuclear Talks Are ‘Not Helpful’
abstract: But Iran’s foreign minister said Tehran planned to participate “calmly and coolly” in the negotiations. Both sides will meet in Rome on Saturday for a second round, Iran’s Foreign Ministry said.

title: China Wants Countries to Unite Against Trump, but Is Met With Wariness
abstract: Beijing is using a mix of carrots and sticks to try to prevent other countries from siding with the United States in isolating China.

title: South Korea Hopes Shipbuilding Will Give It an Edge in Trade Talks
abstract: As it faces the possibility of a 25 percent tariff on its exports, South Korea has taken notice of President Trump’s stated goal to revive U.S. shipbuilding.

title: Will Americans Eat a $100 Tariff on Shein Packages?
abstract: The Trump administration’s plan to add steep fees to packages from China will deal a blow to Temu, Shein and some TikTok Shop sellers, worrying American consumers.

title: Sanders and Ocasio-Cortez Electrify Democrats Who Want to Fight Trump
abstract: Bernie Sanders and his apparent heir, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, have drawn enormous crowds on their “Fighting Oligarchy” tour, energizing a beaten-down Democratic Party.

title: ‘Massive Blackout’ Leaves All of Puerto Rico Without Power
abstract: It was not immediately clear why every generating plant on the island went offline Wednesday. Puerto Rico has a history of problems with its electricity supply.

title: Trump Is the One Who ‘Played It Wrong’ on Tariffs
abstract: Trump thinks he holds all the cards in this high-stakes game, but he’s wrong.

title: Ontario Premier Orders Review of Major Toronto Waterfront Lease
abstract: Doug Ford said he had asked his government to look into the contract that granted a 95-year lease to a European wellness company after a New York Times investigation into the deal.

title: Trump Administration Halts Building of Giant Wind Farm Off N.Y. Coast
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul quickly responded that she would “fight this decision every step of the way.”

title: Michelle Trachtenberg, ‘Buffy’ Actress, Died From Complications of Diabetes
abstract: The New York City medical examiner’s office determined the cause and manner of her death after reviewing toxicology test results, a spokeswoman said.

title: Two-Student Team Stuns the Competition at U.S. Constitution Contest
abstract: Matthew Meyers and Colin Williams of Oregon won first place at the national U.S. Constitution Team competition. Then came the recount that threatened to unravel their achievement.

title: It’s Not Hard to Imagine a Chinese-Led Global Economy
abstract: It has simmering problems of its own, but China is ready to take center stage.

title: Doubts About Trump’s Pitch to Jews
abstract: Responses to a guest essay by Michael S. Roth, the president of Wesleyan University. Also: Older workers and brain health; cattle and pain.

title: Say Goodbye to Your Kid’s Imaginary Friend
abstract: We waited too long to make laws around social media. A.I. has similar problems.

title: This Is What Trumponomics Is Really About
abstract: Why an effort to reindustrialize America is likely to fail.

title: America, This Is an Old and Brutal Tyranny
abstract: Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia should not be in prison. Especially not in El Salvador.

title: Magical Thinking About a Miracle Mineral
abstract: Quick, everyone! Talk about fluoride, not measles!

title: It’s a Mistake to Think the Biggest Problem With Iran Is Nuclear Weapons
abstract: An olive branch is easier to accept when it is offered from the tip of a sword.

title: Two Defiant Presidents vs. a Deported Immigrant
abstract: Readers discuss the case of the immigrant wrongly deported to El Salvador. Also: Harvard’s battle against President Trump.

title: Why Trump Could Lose His Trade War With China
abstract: The Times Opinion columnist discusses what he thinks Trump — and American policymakers — misunderstand about China in the escalating trade war.

title: Why Should I Change My Name? He’s the Problem.
abstract: If one’s name is a brand, then mine is tarnished.

title: Trump’s Tariffs Hurt the Very Thing That Drives the Economy
abstract: Even with his 90-day pause, the president’s approach doesn’t encourage companies to invest.

title: Build Homes on Federal Land
abstract: Public land is a promising place to build what Western cities need most and mostly don’t allow: homes and apartments for low-wage workers.

title: Haiti’s Gangs Have Evolved. The United States Will Pay the Price.
abstract: If the Trump administration is serious about making the United States safer and more prosperous, it cannot stop engaging in places like Haiti.

title: I’m in Denmark’s Parliament. Here’s Why America Has Us So Stunned.
abstract: Danes want our partnership with Americans to continue, but we will stand firm on our principles.

title: Harvard’s Strength and How Far We’ve Fallen So Quickly
abstract: The thrill over its response to the Trump administration is a measure of how low and how fast our expectations have fallen.

title: Expelled From the Navy: 381 Banned Books
abstract: Readers object to the Naval Academy’s removal of books from its library. Also: Measles vaccines; cutting the E.P.A.; a cost to farmers; a plea to our leaders.

title: Two Postscripts on a Column
abstract: Two deeper histories on people mentioned in a recent column: a famous orator and a mother and son who survived the Holocaust.

title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

title: By Redefining ‘Harm,’ Agencies Aim to End Longstanding Wildlife Protections
abstract: Trump officials have proposed changing a decades-old interpretation of a key word in the Endangered Species Act, which would make it much easier to log, build or drill for oil.

title: Climate Change Is Stressing the World’s Blood Supplies
abstract: Extreme weather disasters, increasing as the planet warms, can curb blood donations while increasing demand, a new analysis found.

title: Countries Agree on Treaty Aimed at Preventing Global Health Crises
abstract: The World Health Organization finally reached a compromise on a pandemic treaty after three years of talks. The United States withdrew from negotiations after President Trump took office.

title: Kennedy Calls Autism ‘Preventable,’ Drawing Ire From Researchers
abstract: The health secretary said he would prioritize studies into environmental causes while harshly discounting other factors scientists say are likely contributing to rising rates of the condition.

title: 2 Judges Order Federal Agencies to Unfreeze Climate Money
abstract: The rulings are setbacks to Trump’s efforts to halt climate and environmental funding approved under the Biden administration.

title: Faces From a Meth Surge
abstract: The devastating stimulant has been hitting Portland, Maine hard, even competing with fentanyl as the street drug of choice. Although a fentanyl overdose can be reversed with Narcan, no medicine can reverse a meth overdose. Nor has any been approved to treat meth addiction.Unlike fentanyl, which sedates users, meth  can make people anxious and violent. Its effects can overwhelm not just users but community residents and emergency responders.Here are voices from one troubled neighborhood.

title: What to Know About Today’s Meth
abstract: The highly addictive drug, manufactured almost exclusively by Mexican cartels, is more dangerous than ever. Its use has been surging across the country. Unlike fentanyl, there are no medicines that can swiftly reverse a meth overdose and none approved to treat meth addiction.

title: As Fentanyl Deaths Slow, Meth Comes for Maine
abstract: A powerful stimulant that keeps users sleepless for days and can ignite psychosis and violence has been rattling Portland and its safety networks.

title: Trump Seeks to Lower Drug Prices Through Medicare and Some Imports
abstract: President Trump directed his administration to help states import drugs from Canada. But a proposal to alter a Medicare program to reduce costs could wind up raising prices.

title: Autism Rate Continues to Rise Among Children, C.D.C. Reports
abstract: While the agency stressed that increased screening was most likely behind much of the increase, the health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., called it an “epidemic.”

title: How Trump Might Unwittingly Cut Emissions From Online Shopping
abstract: Fast fashion retailers rely heavily on shipping by air. The president’s tariffs could change that.

title: This Therapist Helped Clients Feel Better. It Was A.I.
abstract: In the first clinical trial of its kind, an A.I. chatbot eased mental health symptoms among participants. The technology may someday help solve the provider shortage.

title: Trump’s Tariff Threat for Imported Medicines Poses Political Risks
abstract: Levies on Americans’ daily prescriptions and other medicines could raise costs, spur rationing and lead to shortages of critical drugs.

title: A Scientist Is Paid to Study Maple Syrup. He’s Also Paid to Promote It.
abstract: Funded by the maple industry, a researcher has exaggerated his findings to suggest that syrup could help prevent serious diseases.

title: Older People Seeking Care for Cannabis Use at Greater Risk for Dementia, Study Finds
abstract: Users needing emergency care or hospitalization were more likely to later develop dementia, researchers reported. That does not prove cannabis was the cause.

title: To Fight Federal Job Cuts, Energy Experts and States Try a New Argument
abstract: In letters to multiple agencies, the focus is on how job reductions at E.P.A., Interior and other agencies would hurt President Trump’s “energy dominance” agenda.

title: One Giant Stunt for Womankind
abstract: Blue Origin’s all-female flight proves that women are now free to enjoy capitalism’s most extravagant spoils alongside rich men.

title: This Kidney Was Frozen for 10 Days. Could Surgeons Transplant It?
abstract: Scientists developed a way to freeze a large mammal’s kidney, which could ease organ shortages in the future. First, they had to see if their method would work in a pig.

title: Man Pleads Guilty to Selling Sperm Whale Teeth and Bones
abstract: Lauren H. DeLoach of South Carolina admitted to importing more than $18,000 worth of sperm whale parts from Australia, Latvia, Norway and Ukraine, prosecutors said.

title: The Many Ways Kennedy Is Already Undermining Vaccines
abstract: The health secretary has chipped away at the idea that immunizing children against measles and other diseases is a public health good.

title: Can You Stop an Outbreak of a Contagious Disease?
abstract: An interactive explanation of outbreaks, vaccines and herd immunity.

title: Their Space Suit, Their Way
abstract: Lauren Sánchez teamed up with Monse to redesign the Blue Origin flight suits with its all-female launch in mind.
